story: A FASHION show which evokes the glamorous style worn by your mother or grandmother in the s visits the area on Saturday night.St Johnrsquos GAC in Drumnaquoile is hosting the show from the Living Vintage Company as a fundraiser in aid of local people travelling to Romania with Habitat for Humanity and the Centre for Cancer Research and Cell Biology at QUB.Living Vintage is a travelling fashion show where models wear a magnicent collection of some of the most stylish haute couture of the forties and fties in a great atmosphere of fun and nostalgia.Owned by sisters Bridget Owens and Marian Keenan, Living Vintage is a not-for-profit organisation.All monies raised are donated to Cancer Research at Queens University Belfast and Habitat for Humanity.The evening will showcase day dresses, suits and evening wear and is rounded of with a stunning bridal show.Bridget said: ldquoLiving Vintage evenings are great fun with plenty of laughs and many happy nostalgic memories.ldquoWe are extremely proud of our collection of authentic forties and fties fashion and all the outfits are accessorised with the appropriate vintage hats, gloves, bags, jewellery and of course, seamed stockings. Of course, some local ladies will also be on the catwalk.Doors open .pm for show at . and tickets are available from Smythrsquos shop, Newcastle, and JRrsquoS, Main St Castlewellan or by ringing Alicia on   and Marianne on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Strictly dancing at Newcastle school
story: A NEWCASTLE primary school are to host a Strictly Come Dancing fundraiser to help raise money for the school.St Maryrsquos Primary School will be staging the night at Slieve Donard Resort and Spa next Saturday, May .Q Radiorsquos Ryan A promises to bring a pinch of razzmatazz to the dance extravaganza as hersquoll be acting as compere for the evening.Dancers include teachers, classroom assistants, parents and past pupils. There will be two fabulous dance demonstrations from European Argentina Tango champions, Anna Arriza DrsquoEste and Marco de Camillis, and  Irish dancing world champions Orlaith Bradley and David Carberry.Jenni Maguire, a teacher at the school, has been putting the dancers through their paces along with former All-Ireland Ballroom champion and choreographer Graham Jack.The event promises to be a great night of entertainment, says Graham,with demonstrations from the world champion Irish dancers to kick start the night followed by couples taking to the stage with a selection of Latin and ballroom dances.He said: ldquoI am really excited about our event. It is a great opportunity to bring the school and community together for what promises to be a real dance spectacular, while raising money for our school.ldquoI couldnrsquot do what these dancers have done. They deserve great credit for putting two dance routines together in such a short period of time.ldquoThe contestants seem to have enjoyed the build up. While there has been pressure due to the time scale in preparation and the work load involved, there have been no tears or tantrums.He added. ldquoThe practices have been good fun. There have been plenty of laughs. The iniduals and couples mix well and we all get on the best. But when the hard work needs to be done, they take it very seriously.Jenni said the couples have put in many hours of rehearsals, given freely of their time and have shown great dedication.She said: ldquoSome have revealed much hidden talent in rehearsals and head judge, UTVrsquos Rita Fitzgerald, will have a tough job on her hands but with the help of the  and votes by the audience on the night the Strictly Ball could be a closely fought battle.One of the contestants, Claire Toner, whose son Dylan is a P pupil at the school, said: ldquoI volunteered as I wanted to do something dferent. It was a case of challenging myself and trying something fun and exciting.One person who has taken it all in her stride is classroom assistant Rachel Lowey. A past pupil of the school, she is paired with another former pupil and friend Shane Kearney.She said: ldquoLike Claire, I wanted to learn something new. Never in a million years did I think Irsquod be dancing on the same stage as some of my old teachers and classroom assistants.None of the dancers have experienced formal dance training before and for some it has been very dficult attending the twice weekly rehearsals.ldquoAs enjoyable as itrsquos been, one Strictly is my limit, said school principal Philip Fusco. ldquoWe hope this will be a superb event, not just for the school community of St Maryrsquos.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming everyone on the night and I have no doubt every guest will leave with a spring in their step.Tickets are available from the school office and are priced at pound for adult sand pound concession. You can also show your support and make a donation through JustGiving page.Many of the businesses, parents, friends and family have already shown their support by sponsoring a dancer. The school would like to express their heartfelt gratitude for their support.Sponsors include: McKeeverrsquos Chemist, Property Directions, ActiSport, Nutty Chef, Cocorsquos, Quinnrsquos, Diamond Patrsquos, Smallrsquos Body Repair and Paintworx, ADS Mechanical Ltd, DTS Plumbing and Heating, Mortgage and Insurance Directions, Mark Samuel Haulage, Kelly Brothers Building Contractors, Medicare, Donard Wines, Tap Room in the Donard Bar, Matthew Toner Electrics  Lick Gelato, Joe Quality Meats, Fitzpatrickrsquos Car and Commercial Repair, ADHD Parent Support Group, Shimna Cafe, Protamino Nutrition Ltd, Blue Beans and BodyRox..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals target playground days after opening
story: THOUGHTLESS vandals have been criticised for damaging play equipment at a recently refurbished play park at the Westlands estate in Crossgar.Community worker Paul Teggart and Rowallane councillors Terry Andrews and Patrick Brown are angry that literally within days of the new facility being opened the equipment was needlessly damaged.Mr Teggart, who worked hard to persuade Newry, Mourne and Down Council to upgrade a previously dilapidated play facility at the estate, said what happened had left him lost for words.ldquoThe new play facility was opened on Tuesday of last week an damaged just a matter of days later. This senseless vandalism has to stop and stop now, he declared.ldquoThe play equipment was specically designed for small children and it is my understanding that the names of people who were spotted in the vicinity of the playground when it was vandalised have been handed over to the authorities.Mr Teggart said Crossgar was a village proud of its mixed community with people getting on well together and working in unison to make it a welcoming and vibrant place.ldquoWe all get along with each other but it would appear that there are several youths who are determined to cause harm and have no respect for anyone or indeed young childrenrsquos play equipment, he continued.Mr Teggart added: ldquoWestlands residents are rightly upset with one suggesting to me that whoever was responsible should be made to pay for the damage they have caused.Cllr Andrews said this ldquowanton act of vandalism was totally out of order and uncalled for, emphasising that it was children who suffered as a result of the ldquodespicable action of others.ldquoI have made local council officials aware of what happened and and hope that the damaged equipment can be replaced. I was proud to see a play park which had been neglected for years rejuvenated, but the damage to the equipment is so disappointing.Cllr Andrews said he had many good memories of growing up in Westlands, explaining that after years of having nothing, it was ldquowonderful to see the play park rejuvenated for so many to enjoy.He continued: ldquoI hope those responsible will be apprehended. The message must go out that this kind of behaviour will not be tolerated.Cllr Andrews said many people worked hard to persuade the local council to redevelop the Westlands play park and are bitterly disappointed that their commitment and dedication to the local community is not shared by others.Cllr Brown said he was ldquoshocked to learn that play equipment had been damaged describing those responsible as ldquothoughtless vandals.He continued: ldquoAll councillors worked hard to deliver this upgraded play park for the community and to see it so needlessly damaged in the first week it has been open is so disappointing and adds to the ongoing anti-social behaviour problem in Crossgar.Cllr Brown said he met with Mr Teggart at the play park to inspect the damage and discuss how the local authority and PSNI can stop such ldquoreckless behaviour in the future.He added: ldquoThis sort of action cannot continue and those responsible will be held accountable..prettyPhoto

title: Voters take to the polls
story: VOTERS go to the polls across the district tomorrow to elect  councillors to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Seventy one candidates are contesting the seats up for grabs in the Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob, Mournes, Crotlieve, Slieve Gullion and Newry areas.With the final day of canvassing already underway and candidates targeting any remaining undecided voters, all eyes will be on the magical turnout number which could decide success or failure for some.Turnout in the  council election was just over % which saw almost , people visiting polling stations across the district.As the local council prepares for its second four year term, Sinn Fein and the SDLP will be battling to become the largest party and it is certainly all to play for.Both parties currently have  councillors with Sinn Fein sources quietly confident that the party will have increased its number of seats once the final result has been declared.What is clear is that the final outcome of tomorrowrsquos election is the toughest to call in decades given the number of interesting battles taking place right across the district.Locally, all eyes will be on Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob and The Mournes which are intriguing to say the least, with the outcome potentially resulting in a dramatic change in the political landscape and some high profile figures losing out.In Downpatrick, attention will centre on the battle between Sinn Fein and the SDLP for electoral supremacy in an area where five seats are available.The SDLPrsquos Dermot Curran, Gareth Sharvin and John Trainor are out to retain their seats, with Sinn Fein aiming to ensure that Oonagh Hanlon and Jordan Madden will secure seats on the local authority for the first time.However, Independent councillor Cadogan Enright firmly intends to retain his seat, with strong support from a number of leading community groups in Downpatrick and Lecale.Add Aontuacute , the Green Party , Alliance , the DUPand UUPinto the mix and the expected dog fight for the fth seat could well be decided by transfers.In Rowallane, Independent candidate Martyn Todd and Sinn Feinrsquos Marianne Cleary will try to upset the current status quo in an area where the five seats are shared between the DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance.Sinn Fein has never held a seat in Rowallane before, but clinching one in a traditional unionist stronghold would represent a seismic sht.The SDLPrsquos Terry Andrews topped the Rowallane poll in , but was only  votes ahead of the UUPrsquos Robert Burgess, who is confident his running mate, Walter Lyons, who polled  first preference votes five years ago, can join him in the debating chamber.Lyons is the only Ballynahinch-based candidate contesting the poll, with DUP sources confident that Billy Walker and Harry Harvey will retain their seats. But with no TUV candidate, what will the  voters who backed Philip Hamilton in  do this time around Independent candidate Todd is expected to eat into sitting Alliance councillorrsquos Patrick Brownrsquos vote, with the Green Party intent on making an impression through Emma Cairns. Aontuacutersquos Liam Mulhern is contesting his first election and with  candidates chasing five seats the election count will be a particularly nervous affair.In Slieve Croob, the SDLP is keen to grab two of the five seats up for grabs with current encumbent Mark Murnin, the local councilrsquos current chairman, joined by party stalwart Hugh Gallagher.Sinn Fein has made its intention clear by fielding three candidates. Republicans currently hold two seats through Roacuteisiacuten Howell and John Rice and are aiming to ensure through the partyrsquos tried and trusted vote management system that Drumaness woman Cathy Mason will also secure a seat.Sitting DUP councillor Garth Craig is not seeking re-election with the party selecting Maynard Hanna to defend his seat, while Alan Lewis is flying the flag for the Ulster Unionists.Alliance currently hold a seat in Slieve Croob through Andy McMurray but he surprised many byopting to stand in the Mournes area, with his position being contested by university graduate Gregory Bain from Clough.The Mournes is another intriguing battleground where former South Down Ulster Unionist MLA Harold McKee is bidding to make ato local politics and the SDLP is aiming toits sitting councillors, Laura Devlin and Brian Quinn.However, Sinn Fein has an eye on one of the SDLP seats and is fielding three candidates, sitting councillors Willie Clarke and Sean Doran alongside Leanne McEvoy.Henry Reilly topped the poll in  while standing on a UKIP ticket. Now an Independent Unionist, he looks set to retain his seat alongside DUP stalwart Glyn Hanna, with all eyes on Alliancersquos Andrew McMurray following his switch from Slieve Croob..prettyPhoto

title: Zak tops Wicklow qualifiers
story: NEWCASTLE ACrsquos Zak Hanna has been selected to represent Ireland in the upcoming European Mountain Running Championships which take place in the scenic Swiss town of Zermatt, at the foot of the world famous Matterhorn Mountain.Living on the slopes of Slieve Croob outside Dromara, Zak travelled down to Wicklow on Saturday to compete in the trial race which would select the team to travel to Switzerland.With this yearrsquos race an uphill only race, compared to last yearrsquos championship being an lsquoup and downrsquo race, runners competing in the trial started at Crone Woods car park on the edge of the Wicklow Mountains and climb along the Wicklow Way trails before entering the open mountain and begin the long and steep ascent to the summit of Djouce Mountain at  mabove sea level-similar to running from Newcastle to the top of Slieve Commedagh.Zak summited Djouce in first place with a good gap over the second-placed runner to add another Irish cap to his list..prettyPhoto

title: ballinamallard supporters pulling out the stops for cup final
story: Trans-Atlantic trips, cancelled plane tickets, hopping back and forth across the Irish Sea. Just some of the trips and sacrices that are being made by Mallards supporters to ensure they are in Windosr Park for the biggest game in the clubrsquos history this Saturday.Kick off in the Irish Cup final is at .pm and the stands will be rocking with Mighty Duck supporters dreaming of the sweetest end to what has been an incredible journey.And speaking of journeys there are plenty being made this week. Former Ballinamallard manager Whitey Anderson boarded a plane in America, where he coaches soccer now, and has landed for the big day.ldquoIt is an occasion not to be missed for anyone involved in Ballinamallard, past or present. To get to a final is just fantastic and it is a two horse race now, he said.ldquoBest wishes to Harry and the back room team and all the players. I always liked managing at Windsor, we actually beat Linfield three times in four years there. To win a cup final would just be unbelievable and a great reward for everyone at the club for all the hard work that goes on.Another Ballinamallard fan who is flying across water is Stephen Armstrong. He hasnrsquot got as far to travel as Whitey as he lives in England but a four hour car journey has to be made to Newcastle before making his flight.A family wedding for his we meant that Stephen was earmarked for baby sitting duties. But a clash with the Mallardsrsquo big day meant some creative thinking was needed, and he found it in the shape of fellow Ballinamallard supporter Scott Williams.Scott lives in Newcastle and his we has kindly agreed to take charge of the two Amrstrong kids, along with her own two kids, for the weekend while her husband and Stephen head across the Irish Sea.ldquoIt is very good of her to let us go off gallivanting for the weekend, Stephen explained, before adding.ldquoWe are due to stay in Belast on Saturday night butballinamallard win it will be hard to resist a trip down the road.Someone better tell Mrs Williams she could have the kids for an extra night!Football writer and UEFA Communications consultant, Laure James, fell in love with the Mallards while covering them the season they were promoted to the Premiership back in . She posted a picture on twitter this week in her Ballinamallard top saying she was ldquobooking flights.Marshall Gillespie, another Fermanagh native who lives in England, and a renowned football statistician is also making his way home for the big day. For a lover of football history a chance to see the first Irish Cup final involving a Fermanagh team was something not to be missed with Marshall tweeting ldquoItrsquos going to be a quare day at Windsor!!Finally, one person very close to the squad has had to rebook flights for a wedding abroad. Mark McConkey, son of manager Harry, and a former player for Ballinamallard wasnrsquot going to miss the chance to see his dad manage a team in the Irish Cup final.ldquoIt is a once in a letime thing. Myself and dad have been through a few things in football and it is a family day for us all. So I just had to be there. Really looking forward to the day and there is a family bus organised for about  of us. We are looking forward it, Mark said before adding that they are still going to make that wedding before the bride is down the aisle.ldquoWe are getting collected at .am on Sunday morning and heading off then so we will be over in good time for the wedding.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: councils knock out blow for historic boxing club
story: The Council has also claimed that Enniskillen Boxing Club which was founded in , ldquohad failed to provide the necessary policies and procedures required by the Council to show that it was acting as a constituted club in relation to Health and Safety, Safeguarding etc, despite numerous requests made by Council officers to the club to supply this information.The response comes after this newspaper asked a series of questions following a letter from a reader concerning the issue.The letter writer asked in last weekrsquos Impartial Reporter: ldquoWhy did the Council, who are supposed to promote and aid such important community cross community organisations which help all ages and particularly young people, close this club suddenly, prematurely and unnecessarily The letter writer also queriedthe area was to be developed moving forward and whether or not the premises could be used by the Boxing club until any development took place.In relation to the future development the Council said that it ldquohas recently carried out consultation on its Draft ldquoActive Together Strategy. Once this is completed the Council will make a final decision on the best way forward.The Council has also said that the premises is at present ldquonot fit for use.ldquoAt present the facility is not fit for use as considerable refurbishment work is required. This includes works to the toilets and showers, heating, flooring and other areas of the centre, The Council stated.Enniskillen Boxing Club was formed in  but has not been operating since last year when it moved out of the premises at Celtic Park.The club has had many notable boxers and successes down through the years.Gordon Ferris, who was a member of the club in its early days won a Commonwealth games bronze medal for Northern Ireland in  before going on to a professional career that saw him win the British Heavyweight title in .In more recent times Shane Curran competed in the Commonwealth games before going on to become a leading coach at the club.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valRather than be outraged by the Belfast Marathon#s switch to a Sunday, some local churches have embraced the change of day for the showpiece event.Some churches have expressed concern about disruption to services while other Christians have disapproved of the decision to hold the race on the Sabbath day, with the Free Presbyterian Church particularly vocal in their criticism.A protest rally at Stormont on Friday held by the Free Presbyterian Church against the Belfast Marathon being moved to a Sunday.Picture Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker PressHowever, the News Letter has learned of a number of churches who will be lending facilities and their support to the runners on Sunday.Bethany Church in south Belfast is one of those churches “embracing” the switch to a Sunday marathon. Its church centre at Finaghy Road South will be set up to offer tea and coffee and toilet facilities to spectators as well as water and jelly beans for participants. They have also entered three relay teams in the race.Support worker at the non-denominational church on the Lisburn Road, Neal Spence, said: “We’ve embraced it. It’s a fantastic opportunity – we’ve got thousands of runners and spectators coming past the front door of our church.“We’ll have a chance to chat to some of the people who have come out to watch from Finaghy about some of the things that we have on at the church.”He continued: “Being a Christian is about imitating Jesus. Jesus was out on the streets, he met people, he engaged with them, he helped them, he gave them a glass of water. We want to be practical in our faith.“Whenever Jesus walked the earth he had the religious elites giving off at him for helping and healing people on the Sabbath. He rebuked them for that. Unfortunately there is still a lot of that religion about rather than embracing this le to the full.“God has given us abilities and talents and the joy to be able to go out and run, for good causes. There’s a lot of good coming out of this marathon.”He said: “I know there’s been complaints, people wanting Christians to boycott it because it’s on a Sunday.“For me, my Christian faith isn’t confined to a Sunday, it’s something I live out each day of the week. We’ll have our Sunday service later in the day to accommodate the marathon.“Church to me is more than just sitting in a building singing songs and listening to someone preaching.”"  "  Man gets reward for finding lost cash Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Rev Colin Duncan, of Woodvale Methodist Church, said his church would wait and see how the Sunday marathon switch affected services before deciding whether or not to raise an issue with organisers. He said: “The writing was on the wall. We could see the move to a Sunday marathon coming a long time ago. It is what it is, we’ve just got to live with it and make the most of it.“We’ll just see who turns up [tomorrow]. We’ll make a call afterwards. Because it’s the first time it’s happened we don’t know what the impact will be. I think ‘wait and see’ is the same approach as a lot of the churches around here are taking.”He did not wish to comment on the religious implications of moving the event to a Sunday.Owen Crane, of Christian Fellowship Church in east Belfast, believes there are bigger issues that demand the attention of Christians than the Belfast Marathon moving to a Sunday.The senior pastor at the non-denominational church on the Belmont Road said: “People in Sri Lanka are getting blown up. That puts it in perspective. I think we can work round the small matter of a marathon being moved to a Sunday.”He added: “It’s a wonderful event for the city. Normally we’d have gone out as a church and done drinks and cheered people on but because of the time it falls it will be right smack in the middle of our services this time.”Father Michael McGinnity, parish priest at St Malachy’s Parish in Alfred Street, said: “Because we’re a city centre church we have people travelling from all around the greater Belfast area for Sunday worship. We would also get a lot of visitors to Belfast attending our services. “We’ve a very loyal congregation and they’ve probably worked out the way they can get into the city centre at dferent times based on the route of the marathon.“There will be some disruption, but I don’t think it will affect us too badly.”In terms of the decision to move the marathon to a Sunday, Fr McGinnity did not wish to comment.Des McKeown, property steward of First Presbyterian Church in Rosemary Street: “Our church is non-subscribing Presbyterian – we take a very liberal view. On the grounds of it being moved to a Sunday we wouldn’t be opposed in the same way that other churches would be, though there would be a wide range of views at the church. “The main concern for us is the disruption it causes getting people into the church.“We’re a central church but our entire congregation comes from the outskirts of the city, not from the centre.“What we’ve done is printed out maps of the route and handed them to everyone in the congregation on Sunday and asked them to do their best to work their way round it. Obviously we’ll understandthey can’t make it.”Recreation on Sunday ‘saddening’A Free Presbyterian minister who is vehemently opposed to the Sunday marathon switch has said that just because people, including Christians, support the event on the Sabbath doesn’t make it right.Rev Paul Hanna, minister of Mt Merrion Free Presbyterian Church, is one of a group of born-again Christians who took part in a protest against tomorrow’s race at Stormont yesterday .He said: “I would have no doubt that many will support it, but that doesn’t make it right. It’s God’s word, God’s law, the mind of God, that’s the only thing that I’m concerned about. “It’s not about whether my message is popular – it’s whether it’s right or wrong.“Society is the poorer for these things that are creeping in to try and reverse God’s Law.“I do think that Sabbath Day sport has a lot to answer for. Sunday is thought of as a day of recreation, a day to do whatever you like. The Lord puts it very clearly that the Sabbath day is to be kept holy. It’s a far cry from what we see today and it grieves and saddens Bible-believing Christians to see it.Rev Hanna said: “The disruption is not the main thing - it’s one day out of  – the main thing is it’s an affront to God and His Word.“I would say there will be people running in the marathon who would otherwise be going to church. “It reminds me of when we protested at Ravenhill . We were received in a very polite way by most people. We preached the gospel, we handed out tracks, we were very positive. The ones who gave us the biggest opposition were actually the people who had been in church that morning.“It wasn’t the neutrals. It was those who are loosely connected with churches in some shape or form.“We’re not out to rub people up the wrong way. We’re out to try and stand for Christ.”Double up for runnersAlmost , people are planning to run the Belfast Marathon tomorrow – almost double last year’s ,. Until now the record was , runners in .The overall size – including the team relay, . mile fun run and -mile walk – takes the total participants up to around , people with large crowds expected right along the . mile route.Organisers believe the rise in participants is primarily due to the move to a Sunday race. Another key factor, they say, is the new faster course which eliminates the climb on the Antrim Road and will have less isolated areas like the Duncrue Industrial Estate section, where there were no supporting crowds.Switch had been planned for ‘number of years’With regard to the Sunday race, Belfast Marathon organisers said: “The Belfast City Marathon Management Team have been working on changes to both the marathon route and moving the event to a Sunday for a number of years due to feedback from all stakeholders, including athletes, city centre traders and the PSNI.“[We] have undertaken a role of engagement with all relevant stakeholders who could be affected by the new route and have received great support from an array of Churches and denominations across the city. Every effort has been made to minimise disruption on the day.”They added: “The Deep RiverRock Belfast City Marathon is inclusive to all and helps raise more than £. million annually for local If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valThe first election in almost two years has seen signicant gains for two centrist parties, with voters slightly moving away from the orange and green direction of the  general election. On the first day of a two-day count which will continue today, most parties faced a mixed situation across Northern Ireland, with local factors and personalities contributing to the results.Kyle Black, son of murdered prison officer David Black, of himself celebrating with his girlfriend Adele Bradley, after winning a council seat in Mid Ulster.However, the two parties for which things were overwhelmingly positive were Alliance and the Green Party, making gains in Belfast where the centrist bloc is now going to be even more signicant in swinging key votes.People Before Profit, the socialist party, also polled strongly and gained new seats, confounding those who believed that its support for Brexit had fatally undermined its support in largely nationalist areas.The DUP polled strongly but its performance will not be clear until the end of the count. The DUP was delighted to see the election of Kyle Black in Mid Ulster, a victory which was poignant because his father, David Black, was murdered by dissident republicans.The party also made history by seeing its first openly gay councillor, Alison Bennington, elected. DUP veteran Jim Wells had denounced her candidacy when it was announced and then declined to congratulate her yesterday.But Arlene Foster made explicit that she stands behind the decision, despite criticism from the Free Presbyterian Church and some DUP members, and Mervyn Storey, himself a Free Presbyterian, did not criticise her selection but stressed ongoing party opposition to gay marriage.Mr Wells was criticised by former DUP spad Tim Cairns, who said that his comments about Ms Bennington were “repellent”.Tom Smith, deselected as a DUP councillor in Bangor East and Donaghadee after he voted to light up a council building in rainbow colours, retained his seat as an independent — a signicant victory against the party machine.Sinn Féin, which had been expected to take additional seats in Belfast after its surge in support in , came under pressure from People Before Profit, Aontú and Alliance, losing several seats in Belfast and where.The Greens topped the poll in the Botanic area of Belfast, winning a seat, and secured a strong vote in the east of Northern Ireland.Alliance had expanded beyond its eastern heartland to contest multiple seats in the west, and some of those candidates broke through. Rachael Ferguson took an Alliance seat on Derry City and Strabane District Council.Sam McBride: DUP cause for satisfaction but SF much to ponder Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"But it was a bad election for the UUP — and especially so in Belfast, where the party once dominated city hall politics.The party found itself squeezed between the DUP and Alliance and struggling to explain a leaflet circulated by veteran councillor Jim Rodgers in which he denounced Alliance, claiming that it tended to vote with “the Provisional IRA’s political wing”.Mr Rodgers, who held his seat but saw his running mate lose his, denied that leaflet had damaged the party.When asked by the BBC why she thought her party was losing ground, UUP councillor Sonia Copeland said: “I have no idea.” She dedicated her victory to the murdered east Belfast man Ian Ogle.The UUP also lost young party officer Alex Redpath, a sitting councillor in Lisburn, and party veteran Arnold Hatch in Portadown.Last night turnout across the areas which had been counted stood around % — almost identical to the turnout in the  council election, which was held on the same day as the European election.The DUP lost its group leader on Belfast City Council, Lee Reynolds, who had led from the front by moving seats in an attempt to win another seat for the party.The SDLP faced a mixed picture, comfortably holding some seats where it had been expected to be under pressure, but losing where.Aontú, the pro-le republican party established months ago by former Sinn Féin TD Peadar Tóibín, saw signs for encouragement in several areas where it contested seats and saw GP Anne McCloskey elected in Londonderry.Counting will continue on Saturday for the remaining seats.try catch  TrendingIf PSNI had shot gunman who murdered Lyra, the cry would be: lsquoshoot to killrsquoN.I. local three places to Arlene Fosters right at the DUP manesto launch earlier this monthAlthough the two were never formally linked, it was the church which provided not just many of the early DUP candidates, but also the foot soldiers who enthusiastically campaigned for the upstart party which would smash Northern Ireland’s political establishment.There were always criticisms from some in both church and party who saw the tension between a secular party with ambitions of winning votes and a fundamentalist church with the aim of saving souls.But those largely lay below the surface until Paisley’s decision to enter government with Sinn Fein, something which dismayed many in the church, who had been taught to view Sinn Fein in theological terms as the representatives of evil. The church gave Paisley an ultimatum: Choose to remain as moderator or remain as first minister. He opted for the latter and, after  years, was replaced as moderator.In his blistering valedictory interview with Eamonn Mallie in , Paisley said that his church critics “do not have the ear of God on this matter [power-sharing with Sinn Fein]”, a claim which appeared almost sacrilegious to some within the church. He also said that his family no longer entered his former church – although his son Kyle remains a Free Presbyterian cleric in England.Then in December  the church criticised the party for allowing retrospective pardons of those convicted of homosexual offences to pass through the Assembly. In implicit praise of the DUP’s nemesis, the church said that the proposal “was opposed only by Mr Allister of the TUV while sadly many others remained silent”. The church said it was “deeply grieved and bitterly disappointed” at the failure of MLAs to oppose the pardons.Now the uneasy relationship between a party which sees the strategic value in secularising and a church which believes that God’s law is unchangeable have ed with the DUP’s choice of Alison Bennington, a lesbian, as one of its council candidates. Ms Bennington has said she is standing “based on what I can deliver as a councillor ... not based on my sexual orientation”, and it is clear that the party leadership has endorsed what in any other party would be a fairly unremarkable stance.Ms Bennington was chosen centrally by the party, itself an indication that the party was taking a strategic decision to test the waters with its supporters. But for a party which once campaigned under the banner ‘Save Ulster from sodomy’ for homosexuality to remain a criminal offence, it is nevertheless a striking indication of how the DUP is changing.Traditionalist DUP MLA Jim Wells, who is currently suspended by the party, has been outspoken about what he described as a hint of “a major – and very worrying – change in the policy of the DUP on social issues”.On Saturday, TUV leader Jim Allister said he was struck in canvassing “by the number of lelong DUP voters dismayed by what they see as their party’s softening on the gay marriage issue because of the Bennington nomination”.Mr Wells yesterday said that “many, many DUP members up to the highest level”, including MPs, MLAs and former ministers, had been in contact with him to express concern about the issue because it was “a huge change in the ethos and tradition of the DUP”.Free Presbyterian sadness at the political normalisation of relations that contravene Scripture Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"The South Down MLA said that there was concern within the party that it was “a step towards other radical change” and that people who had in some cases been members of the party for  years “simply cannot come to terms with this decision”.At the weekend, DUP veteran John Carson, posted on Facebook about the decision. The Ballymena councillor, who is standing for re-election on Thursday, said that he had been aDUP member for  years but “I say quite openly and with no fear of the consequences ‘NOT IN MY NAME’. I first entered politics because of my admiration for Dr Ian RK Paisley and ... I make no apologies to anyone for saying I am an old Paisleyite.”He went on: “I believe in the coming days not only myself but many of us will have some soul-searching to do and some tough decisions to make”. Invoking images of Old Testament idolatry, Mr Carson asked people to pray for wisdom for “those of us who have not bowed the knee to baal” as they “stand against evil in these days”.On Saturday, the presbytery officers of the Free Presbyterian Church issued a statement which was unusually oblique for a denomination known for its full-frontal assaults on those it regards as acting sinfully. The statement, a clear response to the DUP move, did not name the party but said that it “underlines its opposition to all marital and sexual relationships outside the covenant of Biblical marriage”.It added: “Therefore, as a church we are saddened by the attempts of political parties to normalise and promote marital and sexual relationships that are in contravention of the clear teaching of Scripture.”The statement was read out in some Free Presbyterian churches on Sunday, although not in others, in what may be a hint of the church – as well as the party – being split on the issue.Although a tiny denomination, Free Presbyterianism has long exerted an influence which exceeds its size, both through the DUP and its frequent pronouncements to the media about issues of public morals.One church source said that there was a desire among some within the congregation to see DUP party officers who are members of the church disciplined for their role in Ms Bennington’s selection.In response to the church’s statement, the DUP merely said: “Our position on support for traditional marriage is well known and as the party leader indicated last week, it has not changed.”An academic study, published as the book The Democratic Unionist Party: From Protest To Power, four years ago found that the Free Presbyterian Church continued to wield huge influence within the party, with % of DUP members being Free Presbyterian. That meant that Free Presbyterians were  times more common in the DUP than in the population.It has been clear for some time that the DUP is no longer “the DUP at prayer”. Butthe DUP continues on its path to expand its voting base, even the continued high levels of cross-membership of church and party may increasingly become a thing of the past.If that accelerates the It’s not a unique result.“We have seen the Alliance vote expand across Northern Ireland... places where people traditionally write-off the Alliance Party.“I think what it’s down to is the fact people first of all see Alliance offer positive politics... but more than that, they see what the Alliance Party is delivering on the ground.“I don’t think people were voting for Brexit in the local government election. They know that they’ve got another opportunity to do that in the elections that are still to come on May . So I think Brexit only played a very small part in it.”She said Alliance always hears voters saying they want “more integration”.“And then it comes to polling day, and people get in the booth and feel afraid of what may happenthey change their vote. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valIt was a council election which the DUP and Sinn F#in presented in stark constitutional terms.Make your vote count in sending a message for or against a border poll, they said.Yet the story of the first day of the election count has been the growth of the three parties which are the furthest from such tribalism — Alliance, the Green Party and People Before Profit.All three are still modest players, far beneath the big beasts of local politics. But in Northern Ireland’s multi-party system where even the DUP at its zenith has only ever taken % of the vote, small parties can be influential not only in the chambers to which they are elected but in deciding which of the bigger parties’ candidates make it there.The DUP and Sinn Féin remain dominant and there is scant evidence of sustained public move away from endorsing those parties, despite two years without Stormont and public anger at MLAs being paid while not legislating. That is quite an achievement for them.The DUP has particular cause for satisfaction. After a torrid two years of scandal and internal spats, the party seems to have held its ground while smaller unionist parties have failed to do likewise.Sinn Féin has more to ponder. Its  performance, on the back of the RHI scandal, Brexit and nationalist fury at some Arlene Foster remarks, was stunning. But, based on yesterday’s partial results, the upward trajectory has been checked.A combination of People Before Profit, Aontú and Alliance — along with an SDLP which seems to have held its vote better than some pundits expected — has seen nationalist voters channel their dissatisfaction at the status quo in ious directions.But although the DUP will be happy with the first day of the election, there are glimpses of looming risks – but also opportunities for it.The party’s selection of Alison Bennington as its first lesbian candidate was calculated and strategic. The party would have expected a backlash, but might have been surprised at the severity of objections from some traditional supporters.Veteran Ballymena DUP councillor John Carson appealed for people to pray “that this person will not be elected”. Now that she has been elected and the party’s vote as a whole has held up, it is is evidence to bolster those within the DUP who have been arguing that it can liberalise its stance on social issues — at least cautiously — without support collapsing.But beneath some of the headline numbers there are glimpses of future battles for the partyit moves in that direction.Ben Lowry: The DUP now ought to ponder whether it cares most about itself, or about unionismGay DUP candidate Alison Bennington makes history as she clinches victory in election Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"In Bannside, the traditional DUP heartland which gave its name to founder Ian Paisley’s House of Lords title, the TUV saw its vote surge. Having taken two seats in , the TUV consolidated that position. In what may be evidence of disquiet in some DUP heartlands, TUV saw its vote share rise from less than % last time to %.That comfortably eclipsed the DUP’s .% of the vote. TUV canvassers talked about the DUP’s first gay candidate being raised on doorsteps far away from where she was a candidate. If there is a signicant backlash, that is likely to benefit of TUV leader Jim Allister in the European election in three weeks’ time.But the story of the first day of this election count has been the growth of the centre ground. There have been points in the past where it appeared that voters would abandon parties defined by the constitution for a new form of politics. On each occasion, voters have gradually reverted to orange and green.Twenty one years after the Belfast Agreement, the DUP and Sinn Féin framed this as a familiar orange-green contest. Ironically it was a terrorist murder –the sort the Agreement was meant to stop – which disrupted that message and may have persuaded some of those who voted for centrists that they want a dferent title: vale council caves in to arrogant dog owners over proposals to keep off sport pitches
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has said a blanket ban on sports pitches will not be included in a proposed public spaces protection orderaimed at stopping anti-social dog walkers.Dog walkers would face fines of poundthey do not pick up their petsrsquo faeces at sports pitches or other public spaces, and there would also be seasonal bans on some beaches.The sports pitch ban was dropped following public opposition as a petition signed by , people opposed the move.But a consultation answered by , people found per cent supported the banning of dogs from marked sports pitches.Councillor Kevin Mahoney told the councilrsquos Environment and Regeneration Scrutiny Committee on April  that a blanket ban of dogs from sports pitches was the authorityrsquos ldquoone chance to deal with the issue of fouling on sports pitches.He said the ldquosheer arrogance of people to think they should demand that their dogs can go on sports pitches is ldquoabsolutely disgraceful.He added: ldquoIrsquove heard people whining theyrsquove got nowhere to walk their dog, but thatrsquos strange because Irsquom a dog owner and I donrsquot have any problem with that.ldquoItrsquos impossible to clear the complete amount of faeces left by even those so-called responsible dog owners.ldquoThis authority has admitted year after year itrsquos physically incapable of policing dog fouling.The one chance you have of keeping faeces off sports pitches is having a blanket ban so that any dog on there, the owner can be prosecuted.ldquoWho on earth do they think they are  These members of the public who have been so indignant and insistent their dogs should be allowed to do this  And who on earth are the Vale cabinet to agree with them and back down in this way He said the cabinet are ldquocaving into a bunch of indignant dog owners who, quite frankly,they canrsquot find anywhere to walk their dog as I do, they shouldnrsquot own a dog.Seasonal bans of dogs from Penarth seafront and the Knap beach are also set to be removed but dog bans will still apply on a seasonal basis at Whitmore Bay, Dunraven Bay and Cwm Colhuw.Dogs would still be banned from all childrenrsquos play areas, ecological conservation areas and bowling greens in the Vale, and they would be required to be on leads all year round onthe promenade at Whitmore Bay and Penarth seafront and pier.RSPCA Cymru opposed the sports pitch ban but agreed it should be an offence for dog owners not to clean up after their pets.Council leader John Thomas has previously said the council has taken peoplersquos views into account and has achieved a ldquobalanced position.Cllr Lis Burnett told the committee that dog owners had felt victimised by the proposals.ldquoItrsquos been so painful getting here, she said. ldquoIt was so painful for many members of the public who felt they were earmarked for derision as dog owners or dog walkers.ldquoWe need to learn from this exercise and understand that consultation is not engagement. So many people say lsquowhy wonrsquot the council talk to us "Cllr Steffan William askedsports pitches could be ldquofenced off to prevent dogs walking on them, but the councilrsquos operational manager Colin Smith said this ldquocould be quite costly for the council.At the start of the meeting, Mr Smith said: ldquoWe know the majority of dog owners are responsible and we donrsquot want to limit them from the green spaces the Vale has to offer.There were also calls for more dog waste bins throughout the Vale at the meeting.Councillors heard there have been just six prosecutions for dog fouling in the Vale of Glamorgan in the past year.Cardf councilrsquos PSPO against dog fouling will see dog owners fined poundtheyrsquore found without bags or the means of picking up after their pets.But Mr Smith said: ldquoThe legal team were concerned it wouldnrsquot be lawful. In the law it doesnrsquot state what you have to use to pick up the dog fouling. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Last Wednesday, MPs had the opportunity to participate in indicative votes on ious Brexit-related motions.This unusual step came after an amendment was passed securing parliamentary time for debate and a series of votes on Brexit scenarios, to see which,any, might command a majority in the House of Commons.Following this, on Friday the Prime Minister brought her botched deal back to the house again, after what can only be described as political lsquotrickery of the highest orderrsquo.But yet again she was defeated, this time by  votes.This was another huge defeat despite increasingly desperate efforts by the Government to try and cajole people in the last few hours before the vote.I am not prepared to support a blindfold Brexit - so I voted NO. Surely it should be three strikes and out for this deal now And so on Monday, further indicative votes were held as MPs once again took control of parliamentary business ndash despite attempts by the government to shut down our debate before it started.Supporting the move to hold these further indicative votes on Monday, I said: ldquoI think Parliament made remarkable progress the other day in a few hours, compared with the Government, who have had two years to sort this out."It is important that we not only have the opportunity to make further progress tonight, but,necessary, a small amount of time on Wednesday to get to where we need to be, so that Parliament can take control and we can move forward together as a House.And so on Monday evening, there was a hugely signicant result placing a Peoplersquos Vote as the top option for resolving the impasse, with a Customs Union only narrowly missing out as well.I voted the same way as I did last week ndash for a Customs Union for a Peoplersquos Vote, and to revoke Article we face a No Deal Brexit.Itrsquos time for the PM to compromise for the good of the country.We all need to work together to find a solution.We need a credible Brexit option to be put to a public vote in a final say, with the option on the ballot paper to Remain, in order to find a way through this crisis. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: That date has come and gone.Instead we now face the real possibility of crashing out of the EU without a deal on Friday April .We are still no closer to determining what our relationship with Europe will look like than we were two years ago.Understandably, I have been contacted by a number of constituents who look at the shambles in Westminster and just want to know what is going on.Since my last update Parliament has twice rejected Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal by large majorities.MPs have taken control of business in Westminster and the UK Government is openly fighting with itself.On Monday MPs debated for the second time alternative visions for Brexit.The proposals to stay in the Customs Union and for a confirmatory public vote had the greatest support ndash and more support than Theresa Mayrsquos deal ndash but nothing had a majority.The choice of the UK Government to run down the clock have made the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal more likely.Theresa Mayrsquos deal is plainly not going through Parliament but no deal is even more unpalatable.A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit would be bad for Wales and bad for jobs here in Cardf South and Penarth.Manufacturers, trade unions and a wide range of businesses have told us that jobs and livelihoods are at risk.We have already seen that the threat of Brexit is a real factor in jobs that have already left the UK.An industry study has warned that should we leave with no deal it could result in a loss of , jobs, with , of these jobs in Wales.It would cost the jobs of families that I represent.In my government role I have met with health and social care leaders to discuss the impact of a no deal Brexit and to plan our response.We want to ensure an uninterrupted supply of medication and secure the rights of EU nationals working within Wales.Last week I announced the acquisition of a warehouse in south Wales to provide additional storage health and care equipment to ensure there is a continuity of supply for Wales.The Welsh Government has also set up a Business Wales portal to help businesses in Wales prepare for Brexit.It has also created a poundmillion fund to help businesses prepare for the challenges of Brexit.I would urge businesses in Cardf South and Penarth to visit the Business Wales portal and find out about the support that is available.However all of our preparations cannot remove the risk of disruption.A no deal would be highly damaging for our health and care system and the people who rely upon it.I cannot overstate how much time energy and effort has been soaked up in preparing for a No Deal instead of improving our health and care system.No Deal is not a consequence free choice.It is a scandalous waste of our resources and the commitment of our staff.Politicians who bravely talk about a managed No Deal have not had to confront the realities of preparing for it or the scale of waste and damage it would cause.The most troubling aspect of Brexit has been that the isions within the UK are growing.For all my disappointment, Parliament is not enemy territory, as Nigel Farage claimed. That anger and stoking of ision is dangerous and irresponsible.At that same rally we saw a leader of the far right who is a convicted violent racist criminal being applauded on stage.That should not make any us proud regardless of how we voted.The biggest threat to the union of the UK comes from a No Deal.It would not only destabilise politics in Northern Ireland but it would almost certainly guarantee another Scottish independence referendum.More turmoil that would not turn back the tide of austerity or add a single extra penny into our schools, the NHS or any other public service that we rely upon.I do not believe a ided UK Parliament can make a choice for the next generation of our ided countries.I was proud to sponsor two coaches and march alongside more than a million members of the public, including many people from Cardf South and Penarth calling for a Peoplersquos Vote.We need to go back to the people with a choice between a Brexit deal that Parliament can agree and our current deal within the EU.There is no simple choice to the isions that we face but I would as ever be interested to hear views from my constituents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: victoria primary pupils clean penarth beach after inspiring visit
story: As a part of their science topic of Habitats, Year Three pupils from Victoria Primary School, Penarth recently had a visit from the National Marine Aquarium.The aquarium held several fascinating workshops for the children to take part in.The aquarium made use of cutting-edge technology, including Virtual Reality headsets.Using the headsets, the children were able to lsquoersquo more than m down into the ldquoMidnight Zone.The Midnight Zone is one of the deepest, darkest areas of the ocean, and the children had the chance to see the predators and their prey in action.They also explored the food chains found in the seas and oceans of our world.They further examined the impact of plastic on these food chains and their habitats.Following these workshops, Year Three decided to undertake a beach clean on Penarth beach.Equipment was loaned by Keep Wales Tidy, the Welsh environmental charity.The youngsters did exceptionally well on their beach clean, collecting three full bags of rubbish in  minutes.They discussed dferent types of rubbish found, where it could have come from and its impact on the beach habitat and the ecosystem. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new kymin park group to guide future of venue
story: The Kymin, a house and garden overlooking the pier and popular for weddings, had been under threat due to funding constraints, as the Penarth Times previously reported.Penarth Town Council has now said the site will close next year, and will not take bookings from March .The leader of Penarth council Cllr Rhiannon Birch said: ldquoThe town council is proud to have operated The Kymin for the people of Penarth and its visitors for four decades, under a licence from the Vale of Glamorgan CouncilldquoWe had sought a more secure tenure of the site, through Community Asset Transfer or medium-long term lease.ldquoThis would have allowed the financial investment required in the venue but these approaches have been declined by the Vale council.ldquoWith no security of tenure, the council cannot commit expenditure required and has no choice but to close.ldquoWe are proud of the events and hires hosted by the building and the valuable green space it provides in Penarth.ldquoAs the council is no longer able to operate the Kymin, we are now glad to be able to offer community hire space at West House Community Hub, following the improvements to the public community garden under the Penarth in Bloom project.Vale of Glamorgan Council managing director Rob Thomas added: ldquoIt was entirely the Penarth Town Councilrsquos decision to close the building early and prior to the termination date in .ldquoThe Vale of Glamorgan Council was surprised to learn of the decision to close and leave it vacant for the rest of the notice period.ldquoThe council feels that this decision is to the detriment of those who use the site, local residents and the wider Penarth Community, but the Vale council has no power to force the town council to keep the building open,they chose not to.A group is now being set is being set up concerned residents to help guide the future of the Kymin Park.Richard Parry, a regular user of the park, has asked anyone interested in the outcome of the park to attend a meeting.Mr Parry said: "The Kymin Park is an important and lovely part of the town landscape. It is, in many ways, a hidden corner of Penarth with a unique and special character."The future plans for the house will no doubt be a subject of local interest and concern, but in the meantime a number of local people have expressed interest in forming a voluntary group called "The Friends of the Kymin Park."This group would aim to promote enjoyment of the park as public pleasure grounds."Wed also invite both councils to keep us informed of developments so that "the friends of the Kymin Park" could also be a source of good information about arrangements of access and enjoyment of the park during the time that the park management negotiations are resolved," added Mr Parry."Anyone interested is welcome to come to a meeting on Tuesday at .pm in Foxys Deli,  Victoria Road, Penarth to discuss the formation of a group "The Friends of the Kymin Park", specically focused on supporting and developing public enjoyment of the park grounds." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: residents urged to sign petition to ban all animals travelling performances ahead of circus mondao
story: Circus Mondao, a travelling showcase with trapeze artists, clowns, stunts and animals, will stop in the Vale from April  to .But a petition has been launched to ban the use of all animals in circuses in Wales, including by Circus Mondao.ldquoItrsquos just cruel, forcing animals to behave like that, said Linda Joyce Jones, who started the petition. ldquoThey donrsquot want to be there, and theyrsquore forced to travel constantly.Petra Jackson, the ringmistress, looks after the animals for Circus Mondao.ldquoWe look after the animals in our care, she said. ldquoWe follow stringent government standards and guidelines. We place our animalrsquos welfare at the top of our list, and they only make up a very small portion of the show.ldquoTheyrsquore not just animals, theyrsquore part of our family. They want for nothing with us.ldquoThey do travel, but its no more intensive than an average commuter bringing along their dog in the car.ldquoWhen we pitch up, they stay in large, custom built and comfortable enclosures. Wersquore staying at a venue in Rhoose rather than Sully this year, because it is a more secluded area which the animals prefer.Animal welfare is a devolved issue.While it is an offence under the Animal Welfare Act  to fail to provide for an animal properly, a bill will be put forward this year by the Welsh Government to ban wild animals in circuses entirely, though some animals - such as dogs or ponies - are not covered. England will introduce a similar bill in .A public consultation, carried out in Wales in November  and published in January , found that out of , responses,  per cent of responses were behind a ban on wild animals in circuses.But a total of , of these responses were identical, from campaign group Born Free.More than  local authorities in the UK have a ban on animals in circuses, but the Vale council is not among them. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth inventors latest design the zigzag to be produced entirely in welsh factories
story: John Tomalin-Reeves, , has spent the past three years designing and perfecting the ZIGZAG, an outdoor oven designed and made entirely in Wales.Whether itrsquos slow-cooked shanks, sizzled seabass or a speedy margherita, ZIGZAG is designed for budding chefs and enthusiastic cooks who enjoy the great outdoors.The product features an innovative floating baking stone which allows flames to heat food from beneath as well as over the top to create a dual heat source, speeding up cooking time and adding flavour.John has launched a crowdfunding campaign to help get the ZIGZAG into mass production and is asking for help from the people of Wales.Unlike most crowdfunders the final product is already complete.By backing the campaign, pledgers will receive the oven at a reduced price. They will also be supporting local communities and families as once orders are underway, the product will go into mass production in Welsh factories.Much of the product has been made in a family-run steel fabricators in Ferndale in the Rhondda.John said: ldquoI love the fact that the ZIGZAG has been made within  miles of my home in Penarth. Irsquove visited the factory literally hundreds of times in the last three years and that wouldnrsquot have been possibleit was made in China, but what it proves more than anything is that businessmen and women really need to look thoroughly at whatrsquos under their noses.ldquoIrsquove been amazed by the talent Irsquove seen on these shores - there are some incredible businesses here doing some world beating things, and they need our support. Regardless of how you voted in the referendum, whether wersquore in or out we should all be proud of what we produce on this island and Irsquom here to show you that itrsquos possible to create a great product without having to go to the Far East.ldquoIt has taken me three years to develop the ZIGZAG - from the seed of an idea to the living and breathing product you can see today. I want you to support our crowdfunding campaign so we can give a boost to the factories in Wales which have supported our development. Theyrsquore ready to make your ZIGZAG now!Factory boss, Jason Keetch, who runs the factory making the ZIGZAG, said: "It has been an absolute pleasure working on the ZIGZAG with John.The majority of our workload consists of manufacturing sub components for larger designs so we rarely get to make a recognisably finished product like this. Seeing first hand the progression of the design and working so closely with John on it has made this project feel extra special.ldquoMy whole team are proud that the ZIGZAG is a fully Welsh product and that we have been a part of its story. Wersquore excited to see where it now goes!Those who pledge their support and buy a ZIGZAG in the first -days of the crowdfunder, which ends on Sunday  May, will benefit from an early bird price of pound.To find out more, visit: igg.me at zigzag-oven article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: The town has retained its spot in the top ten list, published annually by The Sunday Times.The papers "Best Places to Live Guide " was published on Sunday April .The article praised the town, noting that "The best place to live in Cardf isnt Cardf," but a short journey down the coast.Praise was heaped on several of the towns independent retailers and venues, including interiors shop Benjamins, grocer Windsor Fruit Stores and the Ocho Lounge.Approval for its public spaces, Belle Vue, Cosmeston Lakes Country Park and Penarth Head, as well as the iconic Penarth Pier, was lavished upon the town.The article further quoted Mel Grfin, owner of independent bookshop Grfin Books, as saying the town had a "distinct identity" despite being close to Cardf, and that it has "a strong community spirit."The paper finishes by summing up why The Sunday Times loves it: "Therersquos nothing wrong with Penarth posh".The town of Crickhowell topped the list of best places to live in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Irsquom keeping up my focus on non-Brexit issues though, and have spoken in the Commons on a range of matters including internet safety, plastic pollution and police cuts, all of which affect or matter to constituents in Penarth and Cardf.This week the Government announced a crackdown on internet and social media companies over their failure to tackle extremist and terrorist content online, and content that poses a risk to children - after pressure from myself and others on the Home Affairs and Digital Committees.In response I said: ldquoIrsquom pleased that they appear to have listened to many of the concerns raised by the Home Affairs Committee, including by me and the Chair."I look forward to action on that, but may I press the Secretary of State further on the integrity of our elections, our referendums and indeed our democracy on a day-to-day basis "Particularly in light of recent revelations about millions in dark money that is being spent on advertising to influence votes and to whip up hatred against Members of this House, does he not agree that we need action today, rather than wait months I also raised the issue of funding for South Wales Police in PMQs.I said: ldquoSouth Wales Police is doing a brilliant job in Cardf South and Penarth, in spite of pressures, dealing with kne crime, drugs, domestic violence and so much more, but it does not get capital city funding, unlike other capitals, which makes the pressure worse."Will the Prime Minister look at this again urgently Locally, Irsquove received messages from concerned parents following letters from Penarth and Vale schools about funding and resourcing problems.This is a complex issue but I share the worry and concern felt by many teachers and parents.Although education is a devolved matter, the impact of austerity from the UK government over nine years has impacted on Welsh budgets.Irsquom already in touch with our local councillor team and Vaughan Gething AM, and personally raised the concerns with the First Minister this weekend.Irsquoll provide further information as I have it and suggest concerned parents contact Vaughan Gething AM and local councillors who are best
